Comment: Avoiding c4 and my Budapest-at-test. This is not a good move for white, but it is not straight forward to prove it.
Avoiding c4 and my Budapest-at-test. This is not a good move for white, but it is not straight forward to prove it.
Avoiding c4 and my Budapest-at-test. This is not a good move for white, but it is not straight forward to prove it.
Passively taking a good diagonal. But white has few problems coping with that. The fianchetto has the disadvantage of being announced, so the opponent has time to move according to it.
Already threatening an annoying e5.
Well, this must be a mistake, but let's my opponent prove it.
A doubled pawn is not a problem in this position, even if he cramps me a little.
The bishop has to go to b7 anyway.
Foreseen.
Now I threaten c6. He can take the knight and the other one and double my pawns... so what?
Good move, in order to control my bishop. Ok. But...
Good move, in order to control my bishop. Ok. But...
Good move, in order to control my bishop. Ok. But...
The bishop will be chased away (or exchanged) anyway from the other side. I don't bother to advance the a and b pawns here. Should I?

Now my knight seems to have a nice post on e5, but I must be careful since it can be kicked away with f4. NxB, under this circumstance, is not a wise move, since the white bishop is still almost useless.
...and it will bite on granite. Moreover, I leave room for my dsb to h6. A pretty unusual development scheme.
Here white should have played f4.
I have plenty of pieces on the kingside, and if he doesn't free them with e5 very soon, his pieces would be less active than mine.
I have plenty of pieces on the kingside, and if he doesn't free them with e5 very soon, his pieces would be less active than mine.
Preparing a free way for the lsb.
Now my pawns are ok, and white's kingside is weak.
Now my pawns are ok, and white's kingside is weak.
...because of this.
...because of this.
Here, castling is an attacking move. The break in f5 is on the agenda.
Here, castling is an attacking move. The break in f5 is on the agenda.

Reinforcing my dominiom of the white square, and supporting the strong-looking Bg4. Why I choosed this instead of many other ways to proceed? A good question. It was pure instinct, I must be sincere. Was I right?
